Question Text: Another term for POTS, or Plain Old Telephone Service, is _______________.
Choices:
a. Public Available Telephone Network
b. Public Switched Telephone Exchange
c. Phone Switched Transport Network
d. Public Switched Telephone Network
e. Public Available Telephone Exchange
LLM Explanation: POTS (Plain Old Telephone Service) is another term for the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN). The PSTN is the traditional circuit-switched telephone network that has been in use for many decades. It is a global system that enables telephone communication by establishing a dedicated circuit between two parties for the duration of a call.

Question Text: A baud rate is a measurement of the number of ______________________.
Choices:
a. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
b. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every second
c. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every second
d. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
LLM Explanation: Baud rate is a measure of the number of signal or symbol changes that occur per second. In many systems, one signal change can encode one bit, so baud rate is often understood to be the number of bits per second that can be sent across a communication channel like a telephone line. However, with more sophisticated modulation schemes, one signal change can encode more than one bit.

Question Text: What system did Duke grads build that is still in use today?
Choices:
a. POTS
b. PSTN
c. USENET
d. DSL
LLM Explanation: USENET, a worldwide distributed discussion system, was created by Duke University graduate students Tom Truscott and Jim Ellis in 1979. It allowed users to read and post messages to one or more categories, called newsgroups. USENET was one of the first and most significant examples of a large scale computer network communications system and paved the way for modern Internet forums and discussion boards. While USENET has declined in popularity with the rise of web-based forums, it is still in use today.

Question Text: Which device is used to transfer data across a dial-up connection?
Choices:
a. ATM
b. Modem
c. Ethernet cables
d. USENET
LLM Explanation: A modem (modulator-demodulator) is used to transfer data across a dial-up connection. It converts digital signals from a computer into analog signals that can be transmitted over telephone lines and back to digital signals at the receiving end.

Question Text: Modems take data that computers can understand and turn them into _____ that can be transmitted over POTS.
Choices:
a. Audible wavelengths
b. Baud rates
c. Modulating electrical charges
d. PSTN
LLM Explanation: Modems convert digital data from computers into analog signals (audible wavelengths) that can be transmitted over plain old telephone service (POTS) lines. The modem modulates the digital data into audible tones for transmission and demodulates the tones back into digital data on the receiving end.

Choices:
a. Transmission 1
b. Transportation 1
c. Transmission System 1
d. Transportation System 1
LLM Explanation: T1, short for Transmission 1, is a digital transmission link with a total signaling rate of 1.544 Mbps. It is a standard for digital transmission in North America and Japan, used to transmit a DS1 formatted digital signal.

Question Text: How fast is a T1 line?
Choices:
a. 128 Mb/sec
b. 1.544 Mb/sec
c. 1 Mb/sec
d. 44.763 Mb/sec
LLM Explanation: A T1 line is a dedicated digital carrier line that transmits data at 1.544 megabits per second (Mb/sec). It is a widely used digital transmission service in North America for connecting networks and the Internet.

Question Text: Select all statements that are true of cable internet connections.
Choices:
a. They're wireless connections
b. They're broadband connections
c. They're dial-up connections
d. They're shared bandwidth connections
LLM Explanation: Cable internet connections are broadband connections that provide high-speed internet access over the same coaxial cables used to deliver cable television. They are not wireless or dial-up connections. Cable internet is a shared bandwidth connection, meaning the bandwidth is shared among multiple users in a neighborhood, which can lead to slower speeds during peak usage times.

Question Text: What are the subprotocols for PPP (Point to Point Protocol)? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. FCS
b. LCP
c. Compression
d. NCP
LLM Explanation: PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) has two main subprotocols: LCP (Link Control Protocol) and NCP (Network Control Protocol). LCP is responsible for establishing, configuring, and testing the data-link connection, while NCP is used for establishing and configuring different network-layer protocols, such as IPCP for IP, IPXCP for IPX, etc. FCS (Frame Check Sequence) is a field in the PPP frame format used for error detection, but it is not a subprotocol. Compression can be negotiated using LCP, but it is also not a subprotocol itself.

Question Text: What do you call the demarcation point for fiber technologies?
Choices:
a. ONT
b. FTTN
c. FTTX
d. DSLAM
LLM Explanation: The demarcation point for fiber technologies is called an Optical Network Terminal (ONT). The ONT is installed at the customer premises and serves as the endpoint of the fiber optic network, converting the optical signal to electrical signals that can be used by the customer's devices.

Choices:
a. Wireless Local Area Network
b. Wireless Area Network
c. Wired Area Network
d. Wide Area Network
LLM Explanation: WAN stands for Wide Area Network. A WAN is a network that spans a large geographical area, such as across cities, states, or even countries. WANs are used to connect LANs (Local Area Networks) and other types of networks together, so that users and computers in one location can communicate with users and computers in other locations.

Question Text: In a WAN, what is the area between a demarcation point and the ISP's core network known as?
Choices:
a. a local loop
b. a Local Area Network
c. A local link
d. An access point
LLM Explanation: In a Wide Area Network (WAN), the area between a demarcation point (the point where the customer's responsibility for the network ends and the service provider's begins) and the Internet Service Provider's (ISP) core network is known as the local loop. It is the physical link or circuit that connects the customer's premises to the ISP's nearest point of presence or central office.

Question Text: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a ______________.
Choices:
a. port forwarding VPN
b. one-to-many VPN
c. data link VPN
d. site-to-site VPN
LLM Explanation: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a site-to-site VPN. It is a type of VPN that connects two specific sites, such as two branch offices of a company, over the public internet. The VPN creates a secure, encrypted tunnel between the two sites, allowing them to communicate as if they were on the same private network.

Question Text: Who handles sending data from one site to another?
Choices:
a. T-carrier line
b. CTO
c. ISP
d. VPN
LLM Explanation: An Internet Service Provider (ISP) is responsible for sending data from one site to another over the Internet. ISPs provide access to the Internet and route data packets between the source and destination sites.

Question Text: How many address fields does an 802.11 header contain?
LLM Explanation: The 802.11 header contains 4 address fields: - Address 1: Recipient address (destination address)- Address 2: Transmitter address (source address)- Address 3: Filtering address (used only in ad hoc mode)- Address 4: Optional field used when using wireless distribution system (WDS)

Choices:
a. a collision domain
b. a point-to-point wireless connection
c. an example of an ad-hoc network
d. Individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network
LLM Explanation: Wireless channels are individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network. The frequency band is divided into these smaller channels to allow multiple devices to communicate simultaneously without interfering with each other. Each channel operates on a specific frequency within the band.

Question Text: Which of the following frequencies do wireless networks typically operate on? Select all that apply.
LLM Explanation: Wireless networks typically operate on the 2.4GHz and 5GHz frequency bands. The 2.4GHz band is more widely used and has better range, but is more prone to interference. The 5GHz band offers faster speeds but has shorter range. 1.544GHz and 88MHz are not commonly used frequencies for Wi-Fi networks.

Question Text: WPA3 was built with the intention of replacing which protocol?
Choices:
a. WPA2
b. WLAN
c. WEP
d. IEEE 802.11
LLM Explanation: WPA3 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 3) was developed as a replacement for WPA2 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 2). WPA3 aims to enhance Wi-Fi security by introducing new features such as improved encryption, protection against brute-force attacks, and enhanced security for devices with limited or no display interface. WPA3 builds upon the foundation of WPA2 while addressing its known vulnerabilities and security issues.

Question Text: An 802.11 frame contains a number of fields. Which field describes the version of 802.11 that is being used?
Choices:
a. Sequence control
b. Frame control
c. Address
d. Duration
LLM Explanation: The Frame Control field in an 802.11 frame contains information about the 802.11 protocol version being used. This field is divided into subfields, one of which is the Protocol Version subfield that specifies the version of the 802.11 protocol.
